list.item: Harrison and family ill with flu -

p.del: Dearest family - Sunday night and all in bed but myself - I hope to get my usual Monday letter tomorrow full of good news - Suppose you are busy with Mabel at present - and can imagine - how she is flitting around preparing for her migration to Montana especially busy will she be if she puts in half time at the library. What kind of clothes has she made now? for am sure she has made over something ere this! I wrote her yesterday and also the Pi Phis & mailed a little box to you - a valentine - all of which no doubt will reach their destinations by the end of the week.

div1.p:
This has been a short and yet
a long week too with nothing much to write about in its passing. Harrison his wife and two of the youngsters are in bed with the flu or something similar - all in the same room & in their clothes. Evelyn has been going up several times a day since Thurs when they werecame down with it. She says the place is awful - beds have not been changed all winter I guess. They are much better today however and beginning to have an appetite - The mother in-law is there looking after them and if she stays - poor Evelyn will be relieved of that responsibility. As she had to go over this morning I took her Sunday School class - not a particularly pleasant
task but we got through it - Everyone was so slow this a.m. - we were down at the church-house over two hours - After dinner Abbie & I called on Mrs. Husky - one of Aunt Lydia's daughters and also visited Mrs. Whaley - who lives next Lucrettie's Has five little boys - all but one in school.

B.Y. was as usual tonight - we were glad to come home and have our supper in the living room - Toasted biscuits & had chocolate jetty - potato salad - cookies - Evelyn played & sang afterwards - very nice time.

Yesterday was the darkest & rainiest day we've had so stayed in the house all day - usual tasks kept us busy - Dr. Massy was here for supper & stayed all night - His visits are always pleasant breaks in the quiet - My lamp is beginning to wane so must hurry up these last few words -
There is little news as you see and seven more weeks of school only! Think I shall be glad to see the finish too.
Hoping this finds all well with you both and with loads of love as ever
